author: J Praveen Paul Joseph
text:
Efforts on to fill the pool with sand: City Health Officer

Pooling risks:Walkers affected due to the foul smell emanating from the rainwater stagnating at MGR Park in Tuticorin on Tuesday.— Photo: N. Rajesh

Stagnant water on the MGR Park here has made morning walk an unpleasant exercise for many residents. A stagnant pool caused by recent rains near the walking track is turning into a health hazard for the health-conscious people.

A. Solomon, who uses the track regularly, said here on Tuesday that the stagnant water should be drained immediately. The stench emanating from the pool is unbearable for the walkers. P. Vinayakam said that the civic authorities had not taken any steps to clear the stagnant water.

City Health Officer Pradeep V. Krishnakumar told The Hindu that efforts were on to fill the pool with sand. Anti-larval measures were being taken up simultaneously to prevent any possible outbreak of vector-borne diseases. With indoor and outdoor fogging, steps were on to kill adult mosquitoes. With a total of 144 domestic breeding checkers, source reduction activities were being carried out door-to-door.

Waste material, coconut shells, worn-out tyres and other unwanted things were being removed. Besides, Nilavembu kudineer was also being distributed. A total of 1,570 temporary flood relief camps had been conducted since November 14 and 1, 40, 644 people were screened and provided with Nilavembu kudineer, Dr. Krishnakumar said.
title: Stagnant water keeps walkers away
